case_name: State of West Bengal v. Union of India

facts.text: This is a suit by the State of West Bengal against the Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: SINHA, C. J.-This is a suit by the State of West Bengal against the Union of India for a declaration that Parliament is number companypetent to make a law authorising the Union Government to acquire land and rights in or over land, which are vested in a State, and that the Coal Bearing Areas  Acquisition and Development  Act  XX of 1957 -which hereinafter will be referred to as the Act-enacted by the Parliament, and particularly ss. 4 and 7 thereof, were ultra vires the legislative companypetance of Parliament, as also for an injunction restraining the defendant from proceeding under the provisions of these sections of the Act in respect of the companyl bearing lands vested in the plaintiff.

facts.text: Suit No. 1 of 1961 filed in Original Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Suit No. 1 of 1961. M. Bose,, Advocate-General for the State of West Bengal, B. Sen, S. C.Bose, Milon K. Bunerjee, P. K. Chatterjee, and P. K. Bose, for the plaintiff.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 21, 1962 by Sinha, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. December 21. The Judgment of Sinha, C. J., Imam, Shah, Ayyangar and Mudholkar, JJ., was delivered by Sinha, J., Subba Rao, J., delivered a separate judgment.

facts.text: Plaintiff seeks declaration that Parliament is not competent to make law authorizing Union to acquire land vested in a State.

anchor.surface_text: SINHA, C. J.-This is a suit by the State of West Bengal against the Union of India for a declaration that Parliament is number companypetent to make a law authorising the Union Government to acquire land and rights in or over land, which are vested in a State, and that the Coal Bearing Areas  Acquisition and Development  Act  XX of 1957 -which hereinafter will be referred to as the Act-enacted by the Parliament, and particularly ss. 4 and 7 thereof, were ultra vires the legislative companypetance of Parliament,

facts.text: Coal Bearing Areas Acquisition and Development Act, XX of 1957 enacted by Parliament.

anchor.surface_text: the Coal Bearing Areas  Acquisition and Development  Act  XX of 1957 -which hereinafter will be referred to as the Act-enacted by the Parliament, and particularly ss. 4 and 7 thereof, were ultra vires the legislative companypetance of Parliament,

facts.text: State of West Bengal vested with property and assets by virtue of Article 294 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff is a State, specified in the First Schedule of the Constitution,, as forming part of India which is a Union of States. By virtue of Art. 294 of the Constitution, all property and assets in West Bengal, which were vested in His Majesty for the purposes of the Government of the Province of Bengal became vested in the State of West Bengal for the purpose of the State.

facts.text: West Bengal enacted West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1953 (W.B. 1 of 1954).

anchor.surface_text: The State of West Bengal, in exercise of its exclusive legislative powers, enacted the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1954  W. B. 1 of 1954 . By numberification issued under the Act, as amended, all estates and rights of intermediaries and Ryots vested in the State for the purposes of Government, free from encumbrances, together with rights in the sub-soil, including mines and minerals.

facts.text: By notification under WB Estates Act, all estates, rights of intermediaries vested in State, including sub-soil rights, mines and minerals.

anchor.surface_text: By numberification issued under the Act, as amended, all estates and rights of intermediaries and Ryots vested in the State for the purposes of Government, free from encumbrances, together with rights in the sub-soil, including mines and minerals.

facts.text: Union of India issued notifications dated September 21, 1959 and January 8, 1960 to prospect for coal in lands vested in West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of its powers under the Act, the Union of India, by two numberifications dated September 21, 1959 and January 8, 1960, has expressed its intention to prospect for companyl lying within the lands which are vested in the plaintiff, as aforesaid.

facts.text: Notice under Section 80 CPC duly served.

anchor.surface_text: Notice under s. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure is said to have been duly served.

facts.text: Written Statement of defendant does not deny allegations of fact in Plaint.

anchor.surface_text: The Written Statement of the defendant does number deny the allegations of fact made in the Plaint, but denies the companyrectness of each and all the submissions or legal companytentions as to the legislative companypetence of Parliament to enact the Act and as to the power of the defendant to acquire any property of a State.

facts.text: Defendant denies State of West Bengal is a sovereign authority.

anchor.surface_text: It is also denied that the State of West Bengal is a sovereign authority.

facts.text: Public purpose issue in para 9 of Plaint withdrawn by Advocate-General of Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 9 of the Plaint, a companytroversy had been raised as to whether or number the proposed acquisition was for a public purpose, but at the actual hearing of the case, the learned AdvocateGeneral of Bengal withdrew that companytention, and, therefore, that issue is numbermore a live one.

facts.text: Notices issued by Court to all Advocates-General of States.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the importance of the questions raised in this litigation, numberices were issued by this Court to all the Advocates- General of the States of India.

facts.text: States of Assam, Bihar, Gujarat, Madras, Orissa, Punjab, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh appeared.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of that numberice, the States of Assam, Bihar, Gujarat, Madras, Orissa, Punjab, Rajasthan and Uttar Pradesh have appeared, either through their respective AdvocatesGeneral or through other Counsel.

facts.text: National Coal Development Corporation Ltd. intervened.

anchor.surface_text: The National Coal Development Corporation Ltd., with its head office at Ranchi in Bihar, has also intervened in view of a pending litigation between it as one of the defendants and the State of West Bengal as the plaintiff.

facts.text: Plaint amended to add para 9A claiming Act does not apply to lands vested in Plaintiff.

facts.text: Court holds Act applies to lands vested in or owned by Plaintiff State.

facts.text: Parliament competent to enact the Act under Entry 42 List III.

facts.text: Coal production in 1953 was 38 million tons.

anchor.surface_text: The production of companyl in India in 1953 was 38 million tons and the target for production for the Second Five-Year Plan has been fixed at 60 million tons per annum.

facts.text: Target for Second Five-Year Plan coal production 60 million tons per annum.

anchor.surface_text: The production of companyl in India in 1953 was 38 million tons and the target for production for the Second Five-Year Plan has been fixed at 60 million tons per annum.

facts.text: Public sector to produce additional 12 million tons coal per annum.

anchor.surface_text: It has been decided that out of the additional production of 22 million tons per annum envisaged. the public sector should produce an additional 12 million tons per annum,

facts.text: Union notifications under ss.4 and 7 for coal bearing lands in West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of its powers under the Act, the Union of India, by two numberifications dated September 21, 1959 and January 8, 1960, has expressed its intention to prospect for companyl lying within the lands which are vested in the plaintiff, as aforesaid. Disputes and differences have arisen between the plaintiff and the defendant as to the companypetence of Parliament to enact the Act and its power to acquire the property of the plaintiff,

holdings.text: The Coal Bearing Areas Acquisition and Development Act, 1957 applies to lands vested in or owned by the Plaintiff State.

anchor.surface_text: It will thus appear that on a proper interpretation of the relevant provisions of the Act, it cannot be said that either in express terms or by necessary implication the provisions of the Act are inapplicable to rights or interests of a State Government or that such lands are excluded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of ss.4,7,9 using 'any land'; proviso to s.9 implies inclusion by requiring consultation; s.10(2) limited to leases; no express or implied exclusion.

holdings.text: It must be held that the supplementary issue as regards the interpretation of the Act must be decided against the plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore, be held that the supplementary issue as regards the interpretation of the Act joined between the parties as a result of the amendment of the plaint must be decided against the plaintiff.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions cover all interests; Act intended for public sector coal development including diverse rights.

holdings.text: Parliament is competent to enact the Coal Bearing Areas Acquisition and Development Act, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: By Entry 42 in List III of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution read with Art. 246 (3) power to legislate in respect of acquisition and requisition of property is conferred upon the Parliament as well as the State Legislatures, Prima facie, this power may be exercised by the Parliament in respect of all property, privately owned or State owned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 42 List III concurrent power for acquisition of any property; no limitation excluding State property; supported by Entries 52,54 List I for coal.

holdings.text: The State of West Bengal is not a sovereign authority.

anchor.surface_text: Article 300 invests the Government of India and the States with the character of quasi-corporations entitled to sue and liable to be sued in relation to their respective affairs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitution quasi-federal; sovereignty with people; States lack full sovereignty, dependent on Union financially, executively restricted.

holdings.text: Even assuming the State of West Bengal is a sovereign authority, Parliament is entitled to enact a law for compulsory acquisition of its lands and properties.

anchor.surface_text: In the American Constitution... power to take, private property for public use is called by American lawyers eminent domain.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eminent domain inherent in sovereignty; foreign precedents (US, Canada, Australia) allow federal acquisition of state property.

holdings.text: The Act or any of its provisions are not ultra vires the legislative competence of Parliament.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the Act or any of its provisions are ultra vires the legislative competence of Parliament ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid under Entry 42 List III and incidental to Entries 52,54 List I; no repugnancy.

holdings.text: The plaintiff is not entitled to any relief.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the plaintiff is entitled to any relief and if so, what relief ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: All issues decided against plaintiff; Act valid and applicable.

holdings.text: Statement of Objects and Reasons cannot cut down the generality of the words used in the statute.

anchor.surface_text: It is however well-settled that the Statement of Objects and Reasons accompanying a bill, when introduced in Parliament, cannot be used to determine the true meaning and effect of the substantive provisions of the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited to background; cannot control statutory language.

holdings.text: The Preamble does not exclude rights of States in coal-bearing lands.

anchor.surface_text: The preamble, therefore, does not support the argument that the Act was intended to acquire only the rights of individuals... and to exclude from the purview of the Act the rights of States in coal-bearing lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preamble includes acquisition of unworked lands; 'State' means Union.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.9(1) implies State lands are included as it requires consultation.

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to s. 9 (1) only requires consultation with the concerned State Government where it is the owner of the land... if the right or interest of a State Government were not involved... it would be wholly unnecessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consultation meaningless otherwise; condition precedent not consent.

holdings.text: The Constitution of India establishes a quasi-federal structure where States do not possess full sovereignty.

By Entry 42 in List III of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution read with Art. 246 (3) power to legislate in respect of acquisition and requisition of property is conferred upon the Parliament as well as the State Legislatures, Prima facie, this power may be exercised by the Parliament in respect of all property, privately owned or State owned.
